contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Boulton, Watt and Murdoch.jpg|right|thumb|Boulton, Watt and Murdoch]] [[Image:Boulton, Watt and Murdoch statue detail.jpg|right|thumb|Detail of engine plans]] The [[gilding|gilded]] [[bronze]] [[statue]] of '''''[[Matthew Boulton]], [[James Watt]] and [[William Murdoch]]''''' by [[William Bloye]] and [[Raymond Forbes-Kings]] stands on a [[plinth]] of [[Portland stone]], outside the old Register Office on [[Broad Street, Birmingham|Broad Street]] in [[Birmingham]], [[England]]. It is known locally as ''The Golden Boys'' after its colour, or ''The Carpet Salesmen'' after the partially rolled-up plan of a steam engine which they are examining. They were most famous for improving and developing the steam engine. Sponsored by an £8,000 bequest from Richard Wheatley in 1939, and £7,500 from the City Council, it was unveiled in 1956, from preliminary designs drawn up in 1938. The statue was restored and re-gilded, and replaced in its old position in September 2006. It is planned to be relocated; suggested sites including 'across the road' in [[Centenary Square, Birmingham|Centenary Square]] or at [[Millennium Point (Birmingham)|Millennium Point]] in [[Eastside, Birmingham|Eastside]][http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_19980812/ai_n14172213]. ==See also== *[[St. Mary's Church, Handsworth#Boulton, Watt & Murdoch memorials|St. Mary's Church, Handsworth]] (memorials inside the church) ==Sources== *''Public Sculpture of Birmingham including Sutton Coldfield'', George T.
